content.text: The dungeon rumbles. A Shadow Beast bursts from the abyss, its red eyes glowing. üêâ Your sword shakes in your hands. Swinging the same attack over and over won‚Äôt save you.

The guild master‚Äôs voice echoes:
"Hero, you must unlock the Functions of Power! Define them once, and wield them forever. With each new ability, you‚Äôll strike harder, smarter, and faster."
Tags Introduced

items: FunctionDefine ‚Üí defining a new ability (def).
FunctionCall ‚Üí using your learned ability.
FunctionParameters ‚Üí customizing moves with input.
FunctionReturn ‚Üí returning results (damage, healing).
FunctionScope ‚Üí knowing where your powers work.

content.text: Concept Notes

items: def is a Python keyword that means: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm about to teach the hero a new move.‚Äù
After def, you write the function‚Äôs name (like naming the ability: attack, heal, fireball).
Parentheses () follow (they can hold inputs/parameters later).
The colon : opens the function block.
The indented lines underneath are the ability‚Äôs effect (what it does).

content.text:
def attack():
    print("You swing your sword!")
üëâ RPG Connection: This is like learning a new attack style from your guild master. You know the move now, but haven‚Äôt used it in battle.
Hero Training Drill 1 ‚Äì Learn Attack Ability ‚öîÔ∏è
Mission Briefing: Define your attack() move, even if you don‚Äôt use it yet.

items: Steps:
Use def to define a function attack().
Inside, make it print "You slash the beast!".
Do NOT call it yet ‚Äî you‚Äôre just learning the move.

content.solution:
def attack():
    print("You slash the beast!")
hints: Indent the print line inside the function

content.text: Concept Notes
Defining an ability = learning it. Calling a function with () = using the ability in combat. Without (), the function is just sitting there, unused.

def attack():
    print("You slash the beast!")

attack()   # function call

# Output:
# You slash the beast!
üëâ RPG Connection: It‚Äôs like shouting your attack‚Äôs name in battle: ‚ÄúSLASH STRIKE!!‚Äù
Hero Training Drill 2 ‚Äì First Strike ‚öîÔ∏è
Mission Briefing: Call your attack() move three times in a row to unleash a combo.

content.expected_output:
You slash the beast!
You slash the beast!
You slash the beast!
content.solution:
def attack():
    print("You slash the beast!")

attack()
attack()
attack()
hints: Call the function by writing attack() on its own line

content.text: Concept Notes

items: Parameters = inputs you write inside the parentheses when defining a function.
They are placeholders: the hero doesn‚Äôt know the enemy or damage until you pass them in.
When you call the function, you give real arguments (values).

content.text:
def attack(enemy, damage):
    print(f"You strike {enemy} for {damage} damage!")

attack("Shadow Beast", 15)

# Output:
# You strike Shadow Beast for 15 damage!
üëâ RPG Connection: This is like choosing who you attack and how hard you hit.
Hero Training Drill 3 ‚Äì Choose Your Damage üí•

items: Mission Briefing:
Define attack(enemy, damage).
Then:
Attack "Shadow Beast" for 12.
Attack "Skeleton" for 7.

content.starter_code:
# Define attack(enemy, damage)

# Call it twice:
# 1) Shadow Beast for 12
# 2) Skeleton for 7
content.expected_output:
You strike Shadow Beast for 12 damage!
You strike Skeleton for 7 damage!
content.solution:
def attack(enemy, damage):
    print(f"You strike {enemy} for {damage} damage!")

attack("Shadow Beast", 12)
attack("Skeleton", 7)
hints: Put enemy and damage in the function parentheses

content.text: Concept Notes
return is a keyword that sends a value back to whoever called the function. Instead of just printing, the ability hands you damage/healing numbers. You can store this in a variable and use it later.

def fireball(power):
    return power * 2   # double damage

damage = fireball(10)
print("Fireball dealt", damage, "damage!")

# Output:
# Fireball dealt 20 damage!
üëâ RPG Connection: Casting a fireball that also gives you the damage number to subtract from the enemy‚Äôs HP.
Hero Training Drill 4 ‚Äì Fireball Damage üî•

items: Mission Briefing:
Define fireball(power) that returns power * 2.
Call it with 8, store result in damage, then print: "Fireball dealt X damage!"

content.starter_code:
# Define fireball(power)

# Call it with 8, store in damage
# Print: Fireball dealt X damage!
content.solution:
def fireball(power):
    return power * 2

damage = fireball(8)
print("Fireball dealt", damage, "damage!")
hints: Store result in a variable before printing

content.text: Concept Notes
Global variable = declared outside functions, visible everywhere. Local variable = declared inside a function, only visible there. Python keeps scopes separate to avoid mixing battlefields.

hero_hp = 100   # global

def heal():
    hero_hp = 20  # local (separate)
    print("Inside heal, HP is", hero_hp)

heal()
print("Outside heal, HP is", hero_hp)

# Output:
# Inside heal, HP is 20
# Outside heal, HP is 100
üëâ RPG Connection: Healing in a dream vs. healing in the real world.
Hero Training Drill 5 ‚Äì Fake Heal ü©π

items: Mission Briefing:
Set hero_hp = 50 globally.
Inside heal(), set hero_hp = 999 and print it.
Print hero_hp outside too.

content.starter_code:
hero_hp = 50

# Define heal() here

# Call heal()

# Print hero_hp outside
content.expected_output:
Inside heal, HP is 999
Outside heal, HP is 50
content.solution:
hero_hp = 50

def heal():
    hero_hp = 999
    print("Inside heal, HP is", hero_hp)

heal()
print("Outside heal, HP is", hero_hp)
hints: Print inside and outside the function

content.text: üéØ Challenge Quest ‚Äì The Shadow Beast Battle

items: Define these functions:
attack(enemy, damage) ‚Üí print strike message.
fireball(power) ‚Üí return double damage.
heal(current_hp, amount) ‚Üí return updated HP.
Then write a fight sequence:
Attack the Shadow Beast for 10.
Cast Fireball with power 6 ‚Üí store damage ‚Üí print it.
Heal yourself by 20 (start at 50 HP).

content.starter_code:
# 1) Define attack(enemy, damage)

# 2) Define fireball(power)

# 3) Define heal(current_hp, amount)

# Battle sequence
# Attack the Shadow Beast for 10

# Cast Fireball with power 6, store in damage, then print a message

# Start hero_hp at 50, heal by 20, then print current HP
content.expected_output:
You strike Shadow Beast for 10 damage!
Fireball scorches the Shadow Beast for 12 damage!
You heal yourself. Current HP: 70
content.solution:
def attack(enemy, damage):
    print(f"You strike {enemy} for {damage} damage!")

def fireball(power):
    return power * 2

def heal(current_hp, amount):
    return current_hp + amount

# Battle sequence
attack("Shadow Beast", 10)

damage = fireball(6)
print(f"Fireball scorches the Shadow Beast for {damage} damage!")

hero_hp = 50
hero_hp = heal(hero_hp, 20)
print(f"You heal yourself. Current HP: {hero_hp}")
hints: Use return in fireball and heal
Store fireball result in a variable before printing

content.text: üéâ Week 9 Recap

items: By the end of Week 9, kids master functions as battle abilities:
def defines new moves.
Calling a function uses moves.
Parameters customize who/what/how much.
return gives back damage/healing numbers you can store.
Scope explains where variables work (inside vs. outside functions).

content.text: The Shadow Beast retreats ‚Äî you won with skill, not luck! üëâ Next week: Chapter 10 ‚Äì Dictionary of Secrets (Monster Codex & Spellbook).
üìú Ability Scroll Crafting ‚Äî Pip writes a new move once so it can be reused.

items: def starts a function definition.
Name your function like an ability: attack, heal, fireball.
Indent the function body (what it does).

content.text:
def attack():
    print("You slash!")

items: 1) Define roar() that prints "ROAR!"

content.text: Section: Function Call
‚öîÔ∏è Battle Shout Practice ‚Äî you must *use* the ability you learned.

items: Calling a function runs it: attack()
Without parentheses, it won‚Äôt execute.

content.text:
def attack():
    print("You slash the beast!")

attack()
attack()

items: 1) Call roar() three times.

‚úÖ Solution:
def roar():
    print("ROAR!")

roar(); roar(); roar()

content.text: Section: Function Parameters
üéØ Targeting Lessons ‚Äî choose enemy and damage when you attack.

items: Parameters are placeholders inside def: def attack(enemy, dmg):
Arguments are the real values you pass in: attack("Goblin", 5)
1) Make heal(amount) that prints "Heal for X"

‚úÖ Solution:
def heal(amount):
    print(f"Heal for {amount}")

heal(10)

content.text: Section: Function Return
üßÆ Damage Calculator ‚Äî the spell hands you a number you can store.

items: return sends a value back to the caller.
Store the result in a variable to reuse it.

content.text:
def fireball(power):
    return power * 2

dmg = fireball(8)
print("Fireball dealt", dmg)

items: 1) double(n) returns n*2; call with 7 and print.

‚úÖ Solution:
def double(n):
    return n*2

print(double(7))

content.text: Section: Function Scope
üè∞ Two Battlefields ‚Äî variables inside a function don‚Äôt automatically change the outside world.

items: Global variables live outside functions.
Local variables live inside functions.
A local variable with the same name does NOT change the global one.

content.text:
hero_hp = 50

def heal():
    hero_hp = 999  # local
    print("Inside heal:", hero_hp)

heal()
print("Outside heal:", hero_hp)

items: 1) Make gold=10 globally. Inside spend(), set gold=0 and print inside and outside.

‚úÖ Solution:
gold=10

def spend():
    gold=0
    print("Inside spend:", gold)

spend()
print("Outside spend:", gold)

content.text: Section: Boss Challenge
üóùÔ∏è Boss Challenge ‚Äî Mini Battle System (Functions)

items: Define attack(enemy, damage) ‚Üí print message.
Define fireball(power) ‚Üí return double damage.
Define heal(current_hp, amount) ‚Üí return updated HP.
Call them in a battle sequence and print results.

content.text:
def attack(enemy, damage):
    print(f"You strike {enemy} for {damage} damage!")

def fireball(power):
    return power * 2

def heal(current_hp, amount):
    return current_hp + amount

attack("Shadow Beast", 10)
dmg = fireball(6)
print(f"Fireball deals {dmg} damage!")

hp = 50
hp = heal(hp, 20)
print(f"HP after heal: {hp}")
